vectorData.altText:
As you will recall from your exploration of the peritoneal cavity in gross anatomy, Lab 3, the spleen is an intraperitoneal organ in the upper left quadrant of the peritoneal cavity. Unless enlarged, it is roughly the size of a loose fist. It is kidney bean-shaped, with a hilum in its medially-facing concave surface that contains arteries, veins, nerves and efferent lymphatics. The spleen has no afferent lymphatics.
The spleen has two primary functions:
It functions for blood like lymph nodes function for lymph; i.e. immune responses to blood-bourne antigen occur in the spleen; the spleen releases antibodies and activated T cells into circulation.
It also removes aged / abnormal RBCs from circulation through phagocytosis.

The Structure of the Spleen: An Overview
The spleen is surrounded by a fibroelastic connective tissue capsule, richly endowed with afferent pain  fibres. CT septae (trabeculae) extend from the capsule into the parenchyma of the spleen to incompletely subdivide it. The parenchyma of the spleen is supported by a meshwork reticular fibres stroma that extends between the trabeculae. 
The parenchyma of the spleen includes reticulocytes, lymphocytes and other blood cells, macrophages, and other APCs.  It is organized into two histologically and functionally distinct regions called white pulp     and red pulp     .

Sheathed capillaries open into the splenic cords, and here blood leaves the vascular system. In order to reenter circulation, blood cells must pass through the walls of the splenic sinusoids, into their lumen. This type of circulations is called 
open circulation     .
Red pulp veins flow into trabecular veins, which coalesce as the splenic vein.

imagelib.altText: Slide Talks Icon w speach bubble.png

vectorData.altText: Slide Talks Icon w speach bubble.png

The red pulp consists of blood-filled spaces, the splenic sinusoids (S), between splenic cords composed of reticular cells and fibres, lymphocytes, macrophages, plasma cells & many blood cells (RBCs, platelets, WBCs) passing through. It is in the red pulp that aged RBCs are removed.
The central arterioles of the white pulp become the penicillar arterioles of the red pulp. Some penicillar arterioles are surrounded by macrophages, and are called sheathed arterioles. Antigen that escaped detection in the white pulp can be detected here.

White pulp is dominated by lymphocytes and APCs. Here, immune responses to blood-borne antigen occur. 
Blood from the splenic artery flows into trabecular arteries, and from there into central arterioles. T cells and macrophages dominate around the central arterioles, forming the periarteriolar lymphoid sheaths (PALS). It is comparable to the paracortex of lymph nodes, but here blood-bourne antigen is processed and presented to T cells for their activation. Activated T cells leave the spleen via efferent blood.

B cells form the peripheral white pulp, where activated follicles are seen, this being comparable to the cortex of lymph nodes. Antibodies leave the spleen via efferent blood.
It is in the marginal zone sinuses that B and T cells interact with antigen / antigen-presenting cells.

imagelib.altText: Slide Talks Icon w speach bubble.png

vectorData.altText: Slide Talks Icon w speach bubble.png

Splenic sinusoids are lined by elongated stave cells oriented parallel to the flow of blood. Stave cells are stabilized by perpendicularly-arranged reticular fibres and surrounded by a discontinuous basement membrane.
The spaces between stave cells are only 2-3 m wide, less than half the diameter of a RBC. The blood cells from the sheathed capillaries, now in the splenic cords, must pass through these slits in the walls of the splenic sinusoids in order to re-enter circulation. This does not present a barrier to platelets, white blood cells or young, flexible RBCs. However, RBCs lose their flexibility at roughly 120 days and therefore, older RBCs are excluded from the lumena of the splenic sinusoids and are phagocytosed by the macrophages of the splenic cords.
